pros: If you’ve worked, anywhere, you understand that benefits are benefits are benefits are benefits. Dental is very good, health is marginal. vacation is generous, but it’s difficult to take — and NOTHING carries over to the following year. Eastman does dump a nice chunk into your 401)k) after the first of the year: This is nice. The bonus structure, however, is based upon corporate performance and — given lower than projected earnings and layoffs every couple of years — it’s hit or miss.
cons: It’s not the same Eastman that it was 10, 15 or as recently as just 5 years ago. It’s gone downhill and appears to be struggling with an identity crisis. The people that are relocated to Kingsport really don’t like the area: Many of my coworkers routinely express distain for the area and, as such, are just buying time, until they can get the experience they need and bolt to another job and another company. The facilities are hurting. I am a business history buff, and the condition of the facilities reminds me of the decline of Sears. The plant needs work, but overtime and maintenance budgets have been cut. And, just a few weeks ago, when I was walking across the sky bridge to the Corporate Business Center, I noticed how leaks in the ceiling were STILL being addressed by placing absorbent pads on the floor and repairing buckling carpet with duct tape. The people are, for the most part good, but the men are scared of their own shadows, they’re wimps. It’s sad. Leadership is virtually nonexistent, except to promote their wacky sociology agenda.

pros: You are best here if you want to settle down, flexibility of time is there for work whenever you want
cons: We have yearly increment based on company's performance no further growth in terms of career is here you will do same kind of work from generation to generation, no encouragement or appreciation from management or awards are also not part of this organisation.

review_title: Changing quickly, and not for the better
pros: Good work life balance. Very nice and talented people and beautiful location, where Eastman stays involved with the community. If you're coming right out of school there is a whole community of young engineers to make friends with.
cons: We definitely sacrifice our future success for the good of the shareholders today. We seem shortsighted in our decisions (or lack thereof). In a very risk averse culture we frequently pass up on opportunities for growth and improvement, and consistently resist investments that don't pay off IMMEDIATELY. A lot of decisions that simply don't make sense. I think this comes along with a switch from management that "started at the bottom" within Eastman to external mangers who understand business, but not manufacturing or technical innovation. The qualities that get you promoted are RARELY the qualities that actually make a good manager. Probably as good as any big company, but suffers under the burdens big companies suffer under. I would love to see more drive to achieve and more focus on growth. Another topic, (and I hate to complain because I definitely consider myself an ally) but I don't like the way Eastman is pushing diversity goals right now. It's like it's the only thing that matters, and everyone's too afraid to say anything about it. As a woman in STEM, I absolutely admire the goal of getting more women and engineering in management, however, we go about it SO WRONG. We just decided to not change ANYTHING about the culture, or dig into WHY female engineers leave the company, we just unilaterally made a goal to get gender parity by 2030. Without any other changes, the only way to do this is only hire women (whether they are the most qualified or not) and/or push out men who have done nothing wrong. I wish we would instead improve support for new parents, or offer day care, or adopt flexible WFH policies. All of these would achieve our goals of RETAINING good women, instead of just hiring 90% women with the understanding that most will quit, and ignoring perfectly qualified men. People already grumble about unfair promotions and frankly I'd rather be a minority than equally represented but resented and perceived as unqualified. Finally, Eastman no longer seems to value employees and reward service the way it did in the past. Initial offers are lucrative, but raises are consistently below inflation (3% this year with inflation at 6.5%). This would be fine if the company were suffering, but it's making plenty of money. As an individual handling multi million dollar savings processes but giving up my breakroom coffee because of budget cuts, I am resentful. I truly love the people and community here, but it seems to be leftover from a golden age gone by, and good people (who wanted to spend their lives in Kingsport) are being pushed out.

review_title: Caring culture,  great work-life balance, very male centric

cons: Very male dominated with few opportunities for females beyond first level management. We hear a lot about equity but the org charts tell another story. Often females only reach higher level opportunities when they are at retirement age. Employees at their regional sites do not get the same opportunities, training, or visibility.

pros: Autonomy and talented colleagues in my department
cons: Out of touch. What’s said and what’s done don’t line up. The executive team espouses the importance of developing people and career development yet they recently eliminated the Talent and Learning & Leadership Development functions. It’s also curious the number of female leaders impacted by these choices or offered early retirement in other parts of the organization.

review_title: Losing what made the company great
pros: Great people, good location (if you like mountains and smaller communities)
cons: Company no longer sees employees as the most valuable asset and we are entering the fourth round of layoffs in 6 years. This has become the current CEO's go to method for "costs" reductions. There have also been multiple process safety events since 2017 including two significant events in 2022. The blame then gets pushed down to 1st and 2nd supervisors rather than senior leaders taking responsibility for denying capital requests and under investing in safety and infrastructure projects in order to make balance sheets look better.

pros: Pay and benefits are competitive, even excellent in some cases. Some of the work, goals, and teams are interesting and engaging.
cons: The pace and load of work has become excruciating. Management has become demanding with little to no consideration or compassion for the emotional well-being of their employees. Rushing to the next emergency effort to keep the dividends up has replaced thoughtful, well-planned, courageous team-centered leadership. Punishment and fear have replaced forward-thinking, employee-promoting, coaching and development. You are solely responsible for your mental, professional, and project health. This means that if you succeed, you race to the next project. If you fail, you will be "held accountable". This attitude is now pervasive within operations and technical support areas and is toxifying the teamwork that has made this company great in the increasingly distant past. Their company face is slick-marketed, but experienced, dedicated, caring people are being driven from the company at a sickening pace, leaving the operating and engineering core fragile at best.

pros:
Benefits:
-match 50% of your 7% 401k PLUS an additional no questions asked 5% 401k contribution as long as the company is having a good year (they've done it every year for 5+ years)
-HSA contribution ($500 individual/$1000 family)
-consistent raises (we got raises every year I was there even in COVID/trade war)

Culture:
-VERY friendly (at least in business functions)
-most people are happy to help if they have time
-lots of opportunities to try new roles (caveat in the cons)
-really cool stuff going on with circular economy, I really think Eastman is positioned to take off on this front
-it varies by team, but work life balance is generally great
cons:
-comp is well below other companies, may be on par for chemicals, but I got a significant bump making a lateral move into a different industries (note its VERY low cost of living, but with remote you can have the low cost of living and better comp)
-company moves slow (may just be a function of it being a F500)
-NOT digitally native - I assume they're on par with other chemical companies, and I saw some progress while there but they are just really far behind where they could be.
-if your supervisor doesn't want you to leave your current role they can block you from even interviewing for a different internal role... (Plenty of leaders will give you permission upfront to interview for any role you want, but many others will use this to keep you in place)

job_title: Process Improvement Engineer in Kingsport, TN
pros:
Given projects with real impacts early on
Heavy investment in circularity- plenty of focus, investment, and opportunities for growth if this is one of your interests
Much less internally cutthroat than other chemical companies
Pays well and is located in a low cost-of-living area
cons:
Group Leader and Mentor both left within 6 weeks of joining so I had little support coming online
This is a publicly traded company so everything is driven by quarterly results
Heavy investment in circular economy results in other areas being deprioritized
If you are not willing to live in Kingsport, it may limit your opportunities for success
This could go in either category, but as an engineer I will put it in cons:
The old Eastman focused on hiring in people and keeping them for 40 years. The value the company provided to shareholders was a result of the deep expertise of its technical personnel. The switch now to specialized products in growing markets has prioritized Applications Development, Marketing, and Sales. There is more turnover and a faster paced environment. 
Eastman used to be unique as a larger public company with more of a "family" atmosphere but it is coming more into line with other companies more impersonal company culture.

Constant pressure to reduce cost is in direct conflict with the desire to accelerate digital innovation.
Focus is on short term gains and meeting current year cost goals rather than thinking about what's best long term.

Lots of variety; if you remain open to new experiences and communicate that to your management, you will never be bored, at least for your first ten years.
cons: The pace of work gets faster and more intense every year. Constant and seemingly arbitrary changes in information systems and processes keep us all on the steep part of the learning curve all the time, which only makes it harder to keep up with the faster pace. Even a very simple task like "records management" (deleting documents when no longer needed) is made unnecessarily difficult through new IT "tools" that are mandatory to use. While job opportunities for young people are fabulous, they're not so great for people with 10+ years with the company.

job_title: Logistics Business Analyst in Kingsport, TN
pros: Good pay for this area, good benefits.
cons: Experience is terribly undervalued. At on time a person could hire in, learn the business inside and out, and be rewarded for doing a good job and utilizing the knowledge they had gained. That is no longer the case in much of the company. Over the last decade or so they have begun bringing in new hires straight out of school with no real world work experience, and fast track them to management positions that they are not equipped to handle. Meanwhile the more senior employees are severely overworked to keep things running properly and not given an opportunity to advance because they are "too valued" at their current position. As more senior employees retire you see more and more necessary work falling off, because the fast tracked management doesn't understand why things have needed to be done in a certain way. Having returned since retirement I have found multiple data issues that new hires we not identifying.

pros:
BEWARE this toxic workplace and discriminatory management environment
The one star is for compensation. Hourly rate is one of the lowest paid in the chemical process industry but average to above average pay in the East Texas Longview area
This place is a launchpad, let them train you. Get your Operator III Cert and go work for a real Chemical Plant that values hard working employees
cons:

Management does not follow procedures or care about work life balance
HR is useless
Minorities and Women face daily discrimination and prejudice
The only reason I stayed for 10 years was because they kept paying me

pros: Good culture of teamwork and helping team members out
cons: Work can be unpredictable and workload is all or nothing

pros: Job was easy to get, and paid exceptionally well for the low cost of living. I enjoyed the time I spent with most of my coworkers. Some teams have great work/life balance, but it depends entirely on your supervisor.
cons:
Lots of false promises. I was lured with the promise of being able to work from home once a week or more. I confirmed this with my supervisor, but when I started regularly working from home once a week, I was called into a meeting and told to be in the office “more often” but not what exactly that meant. Eventually, not even once a month was acceptable.

New hires are making more than some more advanced employees they work beside because raises are paused constantly even when the company is doing well.

There was no on-boarding. I received no training in my role.

Being queer is officially accepted, but you will be suddenly passed up for promotions and some of your coworkers won’t be willing to answer your emails after they find out.

I heard jokes at the expense of trans folks in front of an employee whose partner was trans. When I brought this up with HR, they said that the employee hadn’t come forward about the issue, so there wasn’t one.

I was verbally assaulted by a coworker. I went to HR, where they made it clear that they would remove me from the project I was leading if I couldn’t work with this person, so I dropped my complaint.

I saw 3 Black people start and then leave in the short amount of time I was there. When I followed up with one of them, they told me that HR wouldn’t do anything about the racism they experienced.

Few women who are hired into the IT department stay in IT because of the culture.

Get any of the promises that you want to have kept by them in writing.

review_title: Advice: Really keep your eyes open.
pros: Excellent benefits, salary is good.
cons:
A heavy reliance on Salesforce, a reliance that is so detailed, that you are literally working for Salesforce. I was given a poor portfolio (Next to nothing) to sell, It was difficult  to do presentations because I had such a small portfolio, and the interest wasn't there for the distribution base. My manager was a micromanager, who claimed not to be a micromanager. He also minimized my achievements to a point of not mentioning them. But then my deficiencies brought out in great detail. I was not looking for a pat on the head, but to be left alone to do my job. The company is also heavily bureaucratic, Bureaucratic to the point of getting persons in the customer base VERY upset over policies, forms and contracts.  Eastman has a lot of attorneys, so that explains it. 
We had a lot of online training over policies, trade secrets etc.. the culture was so bent on tattling on fellow employees in the training, I could answer the questions on the quizzes pretty quickly, but knowing that. The tattling was so widespread that if someone needed an answer, they could cc your manager to get a quicker response.  
As far as the company as a whole, great people, developed good relationships.

review_title: optics, illusions, hypocrisy topped with no raises.
pros: Good co-workers - good people work in manufacturing. You will learn to be a minimalist.
cons: feedback does not make it to the top - or the top does not care. You will always be tightening your belts. It seems salaried people are being punished ever since the union battle. Delayed raises again......if at all. lol. An ex consultant spends millions on consultants to tell them how to run a company. Consultants like the ones currently being sued for among other things "allegedly feeding the opioid crisis" - The BOD needs to do plant tours. Did the BOD agree to the signing of the Statement of the purpose of a corporation? "Americans deserve an economy that allows each person to succeed through hard work and creativity and to lead a life of meaning and dignity" More and more of our supplies are from India, china, and vietnam - goodbye American jobs. Do our contract forces feel like they are leading a life of meaning and dignity?

pros: Eastman has many different opportunities for engineers. It has a history of treating its employees better than many competitors.
cons: For several years, Eastman has been reducing benefits and engaging in negative performance feedback and rewards, due to "benchmarking" against the industry averages.  We have better than average benefits, so management views this as a cost savings opportunity.  In the last two years they have started forcing the lower management to reduce the bonuses of more people, by larger amounts, as a way to provide funds to reward the high performers. This year there is a forced distribution of "exceeds", "meets", and "does not meet" expectations, with the further addition of "partially meets." They say this doesn't mean "does not meet", but what other conclusion is an employee to come to? They also claim this isn't a forced distribution, but the implementation of the system does indeed force it at very low levels.  This is moving to a system where it is necessary for one of your coworkers to lose, for you to gain.  This kind of system has been rejected as not workable by companies like GE that used it for years.

review_title: Still a good place to work, but  new HR policies are bringing us down!
pros: Great people.  Interesting work. Collaboration is still amazingly good, despite poor HR policies that work to  undermine this.  Cost of living in Kingsport area is very low.  Beautiful area.
cons: Terrible HR decisions recently that have really undermined morale:  1) Forced distribution of 20-25% of employees not meeting expectations, with impact on raises and advancement, which generates the feeling that someone can improve and rise out of the lower 20-25% only by having someone else enter!    2) Setting of "career level" top advancement for most jobs for Bachelor's degree that allows for only 4 promotions over an entire career.  Even though this was rolled out a couple of years ago, the impact is just now being felt by the rank and file.  3) major reductions in benefits, especially medical insurance.  4) Two reductions in force over the last 2 years that have purged employees with long, successful careers at Eastman with a unceremonious walk to the door.  This despite multiple years of double digit growth for the company.

review_title: Proud to be part of a winning team
pros:
Proactively reinventing itself, even though it is currently doing well. Leadership recognizes the danger of being stagnant  and is constantly seeking ways to improve.

Doing well financially.

Solid benefits package. Compared to other fortune 500's I've worked for, Eastman makes a point of offering benefits that employees value, but don't offer immediate benefits to the company. (ie financial incentives to lose weight and have your annual checkup).

No state income tax if you're at the headquarters in TN.

I'm proud of the products we make. I love telling people about all the Eastman products in things they use every day. Most people have no idea how often they use Eastman products.

Feels like a truly American company. Most of what Eastman manufactures is done in the United States. Ask an employee for a quick history sometime, its pretty interesting.

Kingsport TN (headquarters) is a wonderful place to raise a family. Mid size town, excellent schools, nice quiet neighborhoods, very manageable cost of living.

Slow, but sure opportunities to move up if you work hard. They really like to recruit from within.
cons:
Big company, so change can come slowly. 

The organization tries to encourage work life balance, but it is frequently challenging to manage.

Some of my peers don't like how little there is to do in the area (comparing it to a 500k - 1m person large city)

pros:
Brand new headquarter building is nice.  

A pro for the rest of the hiring economy is the exodus of talent from the company.

Some people like Kingsport...it's close to the mountains and the climate is nice...but, if you want any culture, music, theater, entertainment beyond an OK movie theater, or cuisine that isn't fast food this is not your place.

The city school system in Kingsport is very good.  There are a lot of AP classes offered at Dobyns-Bennett High School.  There is a lot of pride in the schools to prepare the students.
cons:
This is a company full of managers and hardly any leaders.  They are process HEAVY and the hierarchical power is nauseating.  Apparently, if you are knighted with a "director" title you are also transferred infallible knowledge.  There is fear and avoidance of anything that might look to come across as conflict...diversity of thought need not apply.  

8 years or so on the journey to becoming a specialty chemical company, and they are still on the journey to become a specialty chemical company.  Their plan is to govern the masses with massive pre-defined processes with little room for creativity or individual and unique, talent demonstration.  

Why is a specialty chemical company hurt so bad with the current trade dispute between the US and China?  A true specialty chemical company should be largely immune...



And, when the going gets tough, the VPs spend two days to come up with the awe-inspiring plan, "Make better decisions faster."  Wow...

pros: Great environment. Safety is a huge priority. Great benefits and pay. People are extremely nice and really care about you. You are given plenty of responsibility and freedom.
cons: Anniston isn’t the most fun place in the world, especially if you are young and single.

pros: Eastman has been on a multi-year growth trend, acquiring multiple smaller sites and several other companies.  The growth has created many opportunities for employees to move up or simply move to fit within the changing organization.  Many older employees have been leaving the company for retirement, further creating opportunity for younger employees.  Although Eastman is a large organization with 2 traditional large sites that have the typical large corporation procedure and management baggage, the values of the people I have interacted with make Eastman and enjoyable an pleasant place to work.  The traditional culture of the company at both of the large main sites (TX and TN) have a strong emphasis on integrity and work life balance that make Eastman the best employer I have worked for.
cons: The corporate insurance is the worst I have had among all my previous employers and coverage has been reduced since I came to work for the company.  Overall compensation packages trend to the middle of the curve for the company, despite the emphasis on hiring "the best talent".  You will not be underpaid at Eastman, but don't expect to have a highly competitive salary.  The company has an extremely rigid salary and compensation practice that does little to compensate high performers through raises.  The primary avenue for increased compensation is through climbing the management ranks, not through technical advancement.

review_title: Working for Eastman is becoming overrated.
pros: Employees can expect insurance and a paycheck. You can expect average wages with a declining benefits package.
cons: Eastman does not care for their employees. We have a satellite human resource representative from another site. Questions constantly go unanswered while employees are left in the dark to figure out what we are losing next. We just lost our gym memberships after moving to a  CDHP. They want you to be healthy, you  just wont get any help from the company to get to that point. I hope you are not used to a Christmas bonus. Eastman's policy is $10 per person. Yes, a slap in the face. If you are a Christian, you probably won't even here Merry Christmas . It is replaced with Happy Holidays.  The   Managers don't listen. Production is a major priority while safety falls to the rear. The managers want all the credit when things are going good, but when things start going bad they want to blame the men in coveralls ( after you told them what was wrong). If Eastman wants to be the number one chemical company in the world they have a long way to go.

review_title: Good company going downhill due to a few bad characters
pros:
Low cost of living in the area
Good pay for the region
Ability to change jobs within the company
cons:
Pretty toxic environment currently with periodic and predictable layoffs tied to quarterly earnings cycle. Costa cares only about the EPS and his own compensation tied to it.  There are a few good leaders but they are either too naive or just blindly drink the cool aid their direct reports are serving up.

Coatings and Inks is a classic example. Back stabbing, sucking up, blatant favoritism, outrageous travel spending, lack of accountability for chosen few, continued drubbings for the rest is a way of life. One of the directors spends significant amount of the departments budget on his frivolous travel and world tours at any opportunity he gets to rack up travel miles and live like a king, not to mention several other unethical behaviors. Cant really blame him if leadership is naive enough to hear his stories and believe him blindly. Hard working and high performing individuals get hung out to dry, sycophants  get rewarded. The division is seeing an unprecedented voluntary exodus of employees and employees who are loyal to the organization are constantly reconsidering their choices.

review_title: Does well to attract young professionals, but does not strive to develop or retain them.
job_title: Integrated Global Supply Chain in Kingsport, TN
pros: The company does offer a good base salary and benefits for recent graduates. Having worked in similar roles at different companies in Kingsport, the compensation that Eastman can offer far exceeds that of other local companies. Also training for new employees, while often dated in its methods of delivery, is very thorough.
cons:
VERY corporate chain of command; especially regarding methods of internal communication. Similar to a LinkedIn Network for example: I’m only allowed to communicate with people who are immediately connected to my job role, for anyone else I must go through several steps to get to whom/what I need. Several of the internal processes are “because we’ve always done it this way”, which doesn’t make for a very innovative work environment. 

New employees are graded periodically through the first year of employment on dated HR fluff words like “adaptability” and “creativity” and less on actual work produced or performance on the job. These discussions with levels of supervision that actually have influence on your career’s success are very politically correct and are not two-sided conversations. There is an eerie feeling of not being permitted to discuss career ambitions with these managers/directors, which makes it difficult to strategically plan an internal career path.

pros:
The people here are truly remarkable. There are many employees who are known industry-wide for their expertise, but almost all of these bright stars are humble and happy to teach new employees. 
Despite management's best efforts, a collaborative, team environment persists.
The company cares about safety and environmental issues.
cons:
Currently implementing a forced distribution ranking system to determine raises and promotions.  
No matter what happens (changing market conditions, overall economic slowdown, etc.) the employees take the hit in the form of layoffs, cost reductions (no training for you!), and canceling raises and promotions

review_title: Ingrained corporate culture with no real will to change
pros: I had no work/ life balance issues, and rarely worked weekends or evenings. Four 9s and a 4 was a nice benefit and unlimited unpaid time off (with support from management, understanding you could be perceived as a slacker, etc.) is definitely a perk...even if it's not frequently used. Cost of living in the area is low and the scenery is pretty. Very little traffic in the area.
cons:
Upper management had a stated goal of changing the culture to make it more inclusive, diverse and high performing. But that was never communicated effectively to the rank-and-file. As a result, anytime someone challenges the status quo, or an experienced hire is onboarded with actual insights from outside the company, the system rejects him or her. 

The current culture is often classified in other reviews (and internally) as 'nice'. This is generally code for 'super passive aggressive.' If you are upfront, direct or honest as your style, you will have an *extremely hard time* being effective or accepted.

Also, if you're a person of color or not the mainstream religion for the area, think really hard about moving to the area. It will be tough. You will see confederate flags on your coworkers' cars, and you will hear disparaging remarks that are ignored (or sometimes uttered) by management.

review_title: Eastman is both a challenging and fun place to work.
pros: I am proud to be an Eastman employee first and foremost because of the value that the company puts the safety of the environment and people.  Eastman will not put those two items in front of profits.  If I could sum up the operating moto of the company in my own words, I would say that it is to operate the plants in a manner that makes the most profit without endagering the employees or the environment.  I am also proud that as Eastman continues to grow into a more global company they also continue to invest and grow manufacturing in the U.S.A.
cons: Eastman used to have one of the best benefits packages in the world but they have had to trim that back over the last 10 years in order to remain a profitable company.  As an employee, that hurts me personally, but I also understand that that is simply the way things have to be in today's economy.

review_title: Management Continues to Lower Moral and Trust in Their Leadership
pros: Collaborative work environment.  I feel like everyone (mid level management and below) generally care for their coworkers.
cons: The downward trend of Eastman continues.  CEO Mark Costa gets a 25% raise yet we are headed towards a second round of cuts and lay offs this year alone.  When the stock holders say "jump", Eastman management now says "how far?" The company spends a ridiculously low amount of money on R&D to be claiming they are a top "innovator" in the chemical space.  Its all smoke and mirrors.  To be a top performing specialty chemical company, the salaries of engineers and scientists sure don't reflect it.  Whats going to happen is a mass exodus of young talent that has been acquired because of the moral, budget cuts and weak compensation packages.  So many cuts have been made that very shortly investors are going to see a drop in safety performance and quality of our products.

review_title: Out of touch executives and ageism a concern
pros: It's a paycheck. Benefits are better than other places although health insurance is getting worse. Some products are commodities and some have potential to be market leaders. Engineers seem on the ball and the science is sound.
cons: How much time do y'all have? Watch out, experienced dedicated workers! Once you reach a certain age, they'll lay you off and hire someone younger for a song. Meanwhile, the overpaid executive team is more concerned about their stock shares than their employees. They get ridiculous salaries and we get raises that don't match inflation if we get a raise at all. CEO emails to employees are usually depressing. Not a motivational leader. Not really a leader at all.  High-deductible health insurance is only helpful in catastrophic cases.  No diversity to speak of. Executive team is mostly old arrogant white men. Very few people of color in the workforce. Too many layers in management who seems more interested in getting products to market with flimsy claims not backed up by testing. (Did someone say it's an ethical company?)

review_title: Great people, diverse work opportunities, ethical culture
pros: Eastman people are friendly, helpful, and always glad to share their knowledge and experience.  Work schedules for most of us allow good work/life balance.  At world headquarters in Kingsport, TN, there are opportunities to work in a huge variety of work assignments without having to relocate or change employers, so you need never grow bored or underchallenged.  I go home each day feeling like I've made a difference for the good of other people (and myself).  The pay is good, especially considering the low, small-city cost of living.  Home-wise, we get the best of all worlds because the Tri-Cities has everything most of us need or want, and there are several good-sized (but not large or crime-ridden) cities within a few hours' drive for those who want bigger-city opportunities on weekends.  Eastman is a good neighbor, helping fund local events and fully supporting the United Way, among other efforts.
cons: The good work-life balance doesn't reach everybody; some business people are attached to their i-phones 24/7, and operators mostly work swing shifts which are hard on the body and mind.  Benefits have eroded over the years (but are still good compared to other employers).  "Benchmarking" seems to mean all peer companies are in a downward spiral as the best companies make a mad race to mediocrity, bringing the average down.  There seem to be artificial caps on promotions so on average, it is a long time between merit reclassifications.

review_title: Not a good place.  Positive reviews are mostly due to internal campaign by management.
job_title: Electrical Engineer, Entry Level II in Kingsport, TN
pros: Good starting salary, friendly coworkers, low cost of living in the area, good experience for your resume
cons:
Do not trust the positive reviews of this company on Glassdoor.  Eastman's mangement has launched an internal campaign to encourage everyone to leave positive reviews.

In some groups, 35 hours of work per week is expected and rewarded.  In some, 60+ hours per week are the norm.  The career rewards are the same, so choose your group wisely.  

Advancement and raises are very slow unless you are one of a select few.  Chemical engineers are valued more than any other engineering discipline, others are treated as "second class" with limited advancement opportunities, slower raises, and your input is not valued.  

Strong focus on personal safety (wear your safety glasses and hard hat!) but little to no focus on process safety.  

Management does not support their employees and there is a great deal of favoritism / cronyism.  Budgets for raises and bonuses continue to be cut even though the company has been making record profits each quarter for the last several years.  Benefits get slightly worse each year.

Poor project management, with most project management functions being passed down to the project engineers.  No engineering standards for most disciplines. 

Culture has shifted from one of helpful people trying to do their best for the company to one of competitive backstabbing.  Engineers are rewarded for what they can communicate to management instead of what they have actually accomplished.  Management has little to no idea of what their employees do day-to-day or what their actual accomplishments and contributions are.

pros: Very positive work environment, collaborative and team focused
cons: Corporate headquarters is in a small town and may not appeal to everyone; however, great location, good schools, and access to regional airports

review_title: If you like Kingsport. You’ll like this company
pros: High base salary. Friendly people.
cons: lack of diversity. Small area.

pros: There are very hardworking, loyal, driven employees.

review_title: Not quite what it used to be but still the best (paying) place in the area to work
pros: In my 21 years at Eastman I have never had to worry about a lay off or plant shutdown. The job security can not be beat by any other company in the area. They pay is higher than other places in the area and the benefits are for the most part better.
cons:
Hourly employees are an afterthought. Every program that the company rolls out to benefit employees is geard for that small group that works a straight day shift schedule. The blue collar workers are left on the outside looking in at things like the wellness centers if we have a family that we want to spend time with. The pay is also lacking for the work that is done. The operations and maintenance workers are a very highly skilled group (for the most part) but the pay is based on local companies not global chemical companies. This is unlike the engineering jobs that have their pay based on a global market. 
Hourly employees have very limited chances to advance or even change areas of the plant if they are unhappy or not satisfied with their current job.

review_title: Only place I ever wanted to work...until they turned on their people.
job_title: Global Supply Chain in Kingsport, TN
pros: None any longer.  Used to be a great company until the current CEO and his cronies obtained power.
cons: In the past this was a great place to work. No longer. Executive Team HATES the people, area, and the company culture and could care less that these things are what made the company GREAT at one time. Read the other negative reviews, they hit the nail on the head regarding management capabilities, moving up via who knows what criteria, rating systems that create internal competition against your own team and peers, below scale pay, benefits that are no longer best in class. In some business areas, expectations of working 70-80 hour weeks. People are now CATTLE and the executive team has created this atmosphere on purpose.

pros: Good pay and decent amenities.
cons: Shift work. Big company mentality

pros: Lots of responsibilities, safety is top priority
cons: Can be overloaded with work

pros: Clear and actionable goals from the top of the company.  The need for continual and aggressive growth in productivity and innovation is truly baked into everything we do.  Everyone works together for the benefit of the company.  Still maintains a truly collaborative environment, even after several years of strong growth and change.  Value different and fresh perspectives.  People are good natured, truly value and care about work-life balance.  Work hard, play hard.  Demand nothing but the best performance you can muster, but also tolerate mistakes and the knowledge they bring.  If mistakes aren't being made, your not trying hard enough, but you must learn from them and move on.  Lots of career opportunities in various parts of the company - you can truly work anywhere in Eastman - very flexible in this way - value diverse experiences from diverse backgrounds.
cons: Can we maintain our special culture as we continue to grow?  Will we embrace modern practices of the big global companies to continue making this a great place to work?  So far, so good!

review_title: Good place for people if you can work OT
pros:
Competitive pay
plenty of overtime 
decent benefits for full time
cons: Forced overtime for most departments

review_title: A good company beginning to follow industries norms to hurt the employees: An engineers perspective.
pros: Until recently Eastman has been an extremely stable place to work.  In fact in the last two weeks I went to to 40 year's at Eastman anniversary parties.  The starting pay is competitive.  The work life balance is good. The area around Eastman is relatively inexpensive to live in. There are lots of opportunities for training and personal development.  Overall, I like my job and enjoy Eastman.
cons: In order to grow as a company Eastman has adopted common industry practices that are making it less attractive to work for.  Recent times have seen drastic cuts in budgets and mediocre raises and bonus even though last we had record profits and exceeded expectations.  Also, unless you are one of a select few, don't expect fast promotions or movement into management.  Eastman attracts people by providing starting salaries slightly higher than its competitors, but keeps costs down be promoting slow and with mediocre raises.  There is no other place like Eastman in the area, so you would have to move to find another decent engineering job.

pros:
I have been with Eastman for over 15 years. As with any job change, I came in with some assumptions / hypotheses about culture and career growth. One key assumption was that I would never be held back from career advancement by anything except my own capabilities - and I can confirm that to be absolutely true. In addition to professional and career growth, Eastman has been very caring and supportive through some serious health challenges that my family has faced - ranging from work hour and job flexibility (e.g. working remotely from the hospital, moving me into a position that required less travel, etc.). The health insurance benefits are also top notch, particularly for a heavy user. 

In case you haven't noticed, Eastman is on a great growth trajectory - really by any measure. We are transforming from a diversified chemical company to a global advanced materials and specialty additives company that is driven each day to enhance the quality of life in a material way. The transformation currently underway at Eastman is truly remarkable, and I am privileged to be a part of this journey
cons: Not really a con, but an opportunity - as we transform to a global advanced material and specialty additive company, we need to be more adaptive and move faster - closer to the customer. With the acquisitions of Solutia and Taminco over the past 5+ years, our global footprint (assets and people) has significantly expanded, so we need to continue to take advantage of and leverage this into a competitive advantage to accelerate growth globally.

pros: It’s a great place to work.
cons: None that I’ve encountered thus far.

pros: Potential for great opportunities, provides great resources for certain jobs, great learning environment given the variety within one company.  Headquarters is not in a major metropolitan area. Surrounded by incredible people in my group.
cons: Good old boy system in many areas, getting fair chances at success becomes game of who you know and not how well/hard you work, required to sell yourself and get your name out there to achieve success, top heavy with young ladder-climbing managers not interested in actually helping the people they manage.  PMP system completely broken with biased and uncontrollled management decisions allowing for inconsistent ratings/rankings that negatively affect employee morale.  Ranking against "peers" has created unhealthy competitive environment where people will step on their teammates to benefit theselves.  Creating unfair peer groups to be ranked against when the playing field is really not level (SMEs vs. generalists, any discipline vs. chemical engineers or chemists). Forced distribution ranking in small high-achieving groups where ALL members exceed expectations otherwise they would not last long in the group.

pros:
- Wonderful people that make for a great work envirmonment
- Nearly everyone you encounter is very compentant and easy to get along with, which makes it easy to get work done.
- A large portion of the workers have family that have worked there and plan to spend their entire career with the company. Having alot of 25+ year people around has made it a great place to learn.
- At a point in time where people are beginning to retire, so there are a good number of opportunities for advancement
- Competative salaries and benefits
- All the different functions are located in or close to the plant so there's excellent communication between business, manufacturing, etc. This also means the scope of jobs available is wide and workers are able focus on their stregths and use resources for areas they're not as proficient.
cons:
- Since it's a small town if you're single when you come to the area finding someone here may be difficult. 
- It's the major technical company in the area, so if a spouse is looking for a job and can't get hired on at Eastman there aren't a lot of other good options nearby.

review_title: Good Place to Work, But Losing Positive Qualities that Differentiate Company from Other Large Chemical Companies
pros: Historically, Eastman has had a non-competitive, team culture
cons: The company has rolled out a new stacked-ranking program for employee performance.  It now includes a "partial meets expectations" category that should represent 15% of a group in addition to the 5% that "does not meet expectations."  These goals tie into the employee's bonus and promotion + career opportunities.  If Eastman truly hires good employees, it is hard to believe that 20% of the population is under-performing especially in light of the two lay-offs (totally 6% of the employee base according to corporate communications) in 2016.  This has caused a lot of concern among employees regarding the continued health of Eastman as a company.

pros: My co-workers are all very intelligent and work well together. Company match for 401k is good.
cons: They are tending to send jobs overseas.

review_title: Solid company, good pay/benefits, difficult to climb the ladder.
pros: Stable company with solid earnings base which should sustain the company for a long time. The culture is conservative and friendly to all. Good work-life balance at the lower professional levels. I like the focus on health. Acquisitions are exciting to be a part of.
cons: My main problem at Eastman is the generally slow movement of employees between jobs. This is improving, but at a slow rate.  You have to be willing to give up personal time to become Manager, more for Director, more for VP, etc.  It would seem that even these "more important" management positions would still need a work-life balance rather than working 60+ hours per week like I see many/most of them doing.  Also, the work schedule is fairly fixed. It may be business or site-specific, but in Kingsport, many business basically require an 8-5 schedule.

pros: Best work culture and infrastructure
cons: Not a great pay and increments

review_title: One of the Best Companies I have Been Worked for
job_title: Marketing Communications Coordinator in Kingsport, TN
pros: salary; culture; supervisor/coworker team relationship
cons: benefit; 401k; insurance; healthcare; career opportunity

review_title: Collaboration is a way of life at Eastman.
pros: Thinking outside the box is encouraged as a way of coming up with new products, and solutions to current and potential customer problems.Collaborating across work groups increases the chance for success, builds a sense of belonging and accomplishment.  When others know what you are working on they can give input from a different perspective.  By including people that may eventually have the project passed on to them, the chance for success is increased because of the trust built up and shared ownership.
cons:
Someone who is very ambitious can claim credit for themselves as a means of getting a promotion.  These strong personalities may also drive the team in a direction it shouldn't be going.  Managers have to be able to handle this type of person while valuing their contributions.  

Because the teams are often male dominated some issues trying to be solved may not be important to the consumer.  In many cases women are the consumer.  They get focused on zero defects instead of keeping in mind the expectations of the consumer.

pros: I enjoy working at eastman
cons: I don’t have any cons

pros: nice culture in the world
cons: not application this moment though

pros: Great Pay, Medical, Dental, HSA, Life ins,
cons: Medical has HUGE Deductibles, Pulling out of Michigan

pros: Ethical, good work life balance
cons: Too many processes Slows decision making

pros:
In IT, things are awesome.  I work with great people on some pretty cool stuff.  I get to stay up to date with the latest technology trends for business and do some pretty fulfilling work.  

My management is fantastic.  They want the best out of me and for me.  They make sure that I'm happy with how things are going and are willing to takes steps if I'm not.  There's lots of flexibility in how I do my job as long as the job gets done.   Work-life balance is fantastic, things are pretty flexible if I need to move around my hours a bit to accommodate my home life.

I feel like I get to be myself here and don't need to hide who I am.  I have met some great friends working for Eastman.   I would definitely recommend working in IT at Eastman.
cons:
Things outside of IT don't seem quite as nice, but I can't really say first hand.  I have heard from some people outside of IT that their line of management isn't great, but I suppose there will always be some of that in a company.  Culture in the different areas can be pretty different.

There has also been lots of turnover lately.  It seems that Eastman has a difficult time keeping younger talent.

pros: good environment to work in
cons: quiet environment to work in

review_title: This company has a huge disconnect between middle management and direct supervisors.
pros:
Flexible work schedule allows employees to work four 9 hour days and have a half day off every Friday.

Direct technical supervision is really good to work for.
cons:
Although the direct supervision is competent, their hands are typically tied by the other 6 levels of management above them.  The pyramid of management at Eastman is ridiculous and the amount of overhead that they require to run a company is overkill.  These various layers of management are completely disconnected from the rest of the plant, yet make many of the decisions that directly affect day-to-day activity.  These people seem to be put into their positions, not because they are qualified, but because of who they are related to through marriage or who they went to high school with.  Eastman, being in a small town, is overrun by nepotism.  

Do not expect any reward for your personal accomplishments.  Eastman rewards based on the fact that "Your hard work will not go unnoticed.  It will pay off in the long run." but the long run is on a 15-20 year scale for this company.  This, in addition to drastic cuts to the benefits package that retroactively affected current employees, is why the turnover is high for employees in the past 2-3 years.

review_title: A company full of opportunities, learning and growth
pros:
Eastman is not a company I would have expected to end up working for given I'm originally from the other end of the country, but it's a company I can't imagine leaving.  I have a young son, so work/life balance is important for me and it's something I experience.  The group I originally hired into was very much like a surrogate family, even coming to visit my wife when she was in the hospital and they even helped me move.  When my previous group leader's grandfather passed away, we bought and planted a tree at his home for him.

Eastman has a strong culture of learning and collaboration.  Since I've joined the company I've learned several new programming languages and statistical techniques, driven by my own interest but with support and recognition from my management.  The culture is also data driven, but with room for additional growth.

Eastman has recognized and rewarded the meaningful accomplishments and contributions I've made but without a feeling of competition.  I love that there's an individual contributor advancement track so you don't have to go into management to get more responsibility/pay/recognition.
cons: Pay doesn't feel competitive when just comparing job titles (although the cost of living does help mitigate this).  If you're not a Tennessee Vols or Virginia Tech fan, don't try and talk football.

review_title: Customer development program will reap benefit in the long run.
pros:
1- focus on commercial excellence, winning with customer by focusing on win-win for both parties.
2- working team is encouraged to work closely with customer's technical organization.
3- bad news is allowed to travel up in the organization to potentially allow for course correction.
cons:
1- need to expand product portfolio in selected industry segment so that we are more relevant to our target customers. Expansion could be done through organic or inorganic bolt-on.
2- need to decentralize decision making unit and allow team to experiment, course correct and, as long as the long term vision is correct, this flexibility will allow for pragmatic and quicker approach to reach our stated internal goal. 
3- focus on listening to customer need. It is ok to tear down our own hypothesis if multiple customers stated their preferred approach because sometimes not every hypothesis that we originally had is the right hypothesis. Be flexible.

pros: Team environment, wonderful culture, very safety conscious, good work pace and atmosphere. There are few places where most folks will drop everything to help you with a project. This is one of those places. Despite being a large company it always feels like they do care about their employees.
cons: Slow promotion growth with regard to other companies, over-complicated IT systems for engineering use, sometimes experience lack of adaptability/openness to change and new ideas. Some areas are hesitant to change or take risks since it is outside their comfort zone. Change also seems to take a great length of time to implement and tends to grossly lag what you may find other places.

pros: everything is fall into pro
cons: Nothing fall into con of this

pros: People and work culture is amazing
cons: I don't see any major Cons

review_title: Great company to work for now but concerned about future; Eastman can do better
pros:
-Great people to work with and learn from
-Strong culture of teamwork and collaboration
-Opportunity to rotate to new positions every few years while remaining in Kingsport
-Opportunity for international rotations 
-Invest time and money in the professional development of engineers
-Better than average job security and work/personal life balance
cons:
Recent changes to HR policies are concerning and include:

-Forced employee ranking which is already poisoning the culture of teamwork and collaboration 
-Reducing or eliminating recruiting and hiring from many great schools in favor of hiring only from a smaller group of HR determined "focus schools" will reduce diversity of thought and skill
-Focus on Health and Wellness, a worthwhile goal in concept, has been taken in some cases to an extreme of "fat-shaming" and/or invasion of personal health matters

job_title: Mechanical Engineering Co-Op in Kingsport, TN
pros: Great people, work-life balance and opportunities for growth.
cons: There is nothing bad to say.

pros: Large well organized company with broad opportunities.
cons: Politics and other typical issues that go along with corporate environment.

review_title: Over a long career I have always found Eastman to be an exceptional place to work!
pros: The company is extremely well managed with strong and capable leadership at all levels. The focus on safety, both personal and process, is relentless in an extremely caring and ethical way. A great deal of attention is paid to employee development and satisfaction to allow each person to contribute to their full potential and to be amply rewarded for it. There is a very team-oriented and collaborative work culture throughout the company. The desire to help each other in every way possible is pervasive throughout the company on a daily basis. There is great alignment of purpose through all levels of management. Leadership communication with all employees is excellent!
cons: In a highly competiitive business situation there is a constant need to be sure the company is doing all that it takes on all fronts to achieve and sustain success. Sometimes there are changes needed that are difficult to explain well enough to ensure that everyone is totally satisfied with the changes. If asked about cons some emplyees might think there have been "take-aways" in benefits over the years that weren't truly necessary. In reality, all the changes have been critical to on-going business success and company management has worked very hard to help everyone understand.

review_title: worst employer ever, I am leaving asap
pros:
Very good people work here and most are experts in their jobs.
At the exception of management, employees tend to be friendly, exactly what you would imagine from a small american community.
cons:
1) Not opened for diversity, most management comes from the US and has no clue about cultural differences, this company is everything but global and is not willing to change on this aspect.
2) No respect for people, management feels entitled to yell and humiliate employees, I guess they do the same at their kingsport fastfood if they are not happy with their cheesburger, it is a question of education... sad ...
3) Micromanagement is so present that it should be part of core values, I have seen the very top get involved in operational matters and mess it up. In the meantime the titanic is sinking
4)Kingsport... unless you were born there or are escaping a war zone, why on earth would you live there?
5) If you ever wondered why Eastman is well ranked on GD just google Kingsport... yes ... there is nothing else, people have no other choice... sorry they do, they have the fastfood and the grocery store 
6)Given its current poor performance, Eastman will be a prey for other chemical giants and in this very competitive world it means big synergies for an overstaffed company. Big diet still to come.

review_title: might be cutting too much cost
pros:
Absolutely amazing company to work for.  The team environment is second to none here

The company is growing by leaps and bounds.   

Safety Culture is amazing

very ethical as well
cons:
The company is experiencing some growing pains from having expanded so quickly.  Some of the systems struggle to accommodate the new size of the company.

Eastman has probably gone too far in an effort to not be like Kodak with its cost cutting initiatives.  As a result, the differences between the haves and the have not's in the company are growing, and benefits are not as good as they could be.

Also, not the most transparent company in terms of managing employees careers.

*I realize I gave 5 stars and wrote more in the cons column, but the cons are specific and addressable.  They in no way outweigh the positives of working for Eastman and the direction the company is headed in.

review_title: Used to be a 5 star company now a 2-3 star
pros: The company and the people are great, we make many amazing products and are great innovators. I been with the company for a few years now and I have seen a downhill effect, and only wish they read some of these reviews and the internal surveys and take them to heart. Benefits are great and company is understanding.
cons: Pay is, OK. Not the best and not the worst. They are slow to react to easy solutions and they need to get in touch with the employeess and sales team and make changes based on that and what people see in the field. They are too focused on cutting costs and to the "investors" its kinda annoying, Yes its important but focus on the basics and that will all work it self out.

review_title: Eastman is very ethical and exudes integrity. They exhibit a genuine concern for their employees
job_title: Integrated Global Supply Chain in Kingsport, TN
pros: I like that Eastman isn't afraid to show their faith filled roots from East Tennessee.  It's the first company I've ever worked for that the CEO reminds us of the National Day of Prayer... i think that is awesome.
cons: If you come in from outside East Tennessee I beleive it's a bit harder to break into the inner circle.  However,  I think it's gotten so much better as more and more people join the company from around the country and around the globe.

pros: I have been working with Eastman for over 20years in from entry level engineering  to management.    I have had opportunities to travel, learn and grow personally and professionally.  The training and support given to the employees is superb.  Throughout my career, I have given freedom and support to pick up the ball and run.  Compensation is above average for the area.   Eastman employees pride themselves on being ethical and hardworking.
cons: Recent changes in benefits have the net effect of a pay cut.  Senior leadership seems out of touch with the manufacturing employee and come across as egomaniacs. . We are a manufacturing company not a sales and marketing company but doesn't feel that way sometimes.

pros:
Team-oriented environment
Opportunities and encouragement for career growth
cons: Swing shift schedule can be tiresome. But you are aware of this going into the job.

review_title: Freedom to do the right thing using your insights and conscience
job_title: Regional Support, Not Bo-related (Title Would Give Me Away) in Capelle
pros:
Across the board, management recognizes special talents and skills and gives one the space to use them. It appreciates a broad range of experience, nationalities, opions and backgrounds. That's what makes it s bubbling place to work. 
Eastman is an ethical, respectful company which trusts its people's judgement. It lets us to use our judgement and conscience to do what we believe is right, rather than prescribing all the steps as some employers do. We are encouraged to keep learning new things, and there are plenty of training opportunities within the company.
cons:
The various divisions are, well, divided. With all the talent and knowledge we have within Eastman, we could gain so much by working across organisations! 
We're often too bureaucratic, much of which comes from Kingsport. While meant to reduce risks, it slows us down where we can't afford to be slow. This has an impact both on employees and customers.

review_title: HOSTILE WORK ENVIRONMENT!!! Homophobic, Racist, Redneck Good Old Boys run Eastman Chemical...
job_title: Chemical Plant Operator in Longview, TX
pros: They pay you every two weeks ($31.46 hour Operator)... Small yearly bonus (some years)... Bare bones health insurance... 40 hours of paid vacation each year...
cons: Company is ran by racist homophobic goof old boys!!! Few opportunities for advancement unless you related to someone in a position of power. Forced to work an insane amount of overtime due to manpower shortages. Lower than average pay. Operators and Maintenance workers are not valued by the company. Day workers and office personnel are given priority within the company.

review_title: Rewarding career with a company that cares for their employees
pros: Eastman's impact on its employees, the industry, and the community can be seen daily. The company offers a competitive work environment without feeling the need to work 80 hours a week. No matter your career path, you can be assured that you will have the opportunity to learn and grow if you choose to do so. The size of Eastman and ease to move within the company means one can have multiple careers without ever leaving the company, and travel all over the world if desired. The health programs and workout facilities offered are incredible. Eastman strives hard to make each employee feel like they make a difference and that each day counts. They take safety very seriously, which can seem overbearing at times, but has made a huge impact on how each employee goes through their daily routines at work AND at home. Eastman pours time and money into the community through the United Way and countless other ways.
cons: In a word: bureaucracy. But then again, Eastman is a large global corporation, so what would you expect? However, day to day, it can be overbearing and distracting from work that really needs to happen. Also, it seems sometimes like Eastman makes leeps and bounds to force numbers/figures into the right range or make metrics align with goals, just to suit management and our stakeholders.

review_title: Do Not Recommend Eastman to Prospective Employees
pros: By far, the best part about Eastman is the people.  I appreciate getting to learn from and work alongside industry leading experts.  The collaborative, team focused, and fun culture makes coming into work every day easy.
cons:
Every year for the past 5 or so years, Eastman has made changes to reduce employee compensation and benefits.  After a competitive starting salary, raises are small and you quickly end up way below industry average.  Promotions are slow and hard to come by.  They set a new highest promotion level you can reach if you have a bachelors degree, and if they stick to it, you should only expect 4 promotions in your entire career!

They also implemented a forced distribution ranking system that includes a Partially Meets Expectations (15%) and Does Not Meet Expectations (5%) level.  It's pretty ridiculous to tell 20% of the company that they are performing below expectations.  This has significantly impacted morale and I've never seen so many people dissatisfied and actively pursuing other jobs. 

After two rounds of layoffs and no promotions, no bonuses, and minimal raises last year, you'd expect some kind of relief for employees this year, but no.  Budgets are flat, training and employee development is almost non-existent, everyone is working incredibly hard, but they are still being ranked and not rewarded.

pros: Great pay and good benefits
cons: Swing shift, overtime scheduling could be better

pros: Competitive pay with great people
cons: It is a demanding manufacturing work environment

review_title: The results of Insight...and a lot of fine people.
pros: Eastman's tagline "The results of Insight" is a clue to why it's a special place to work -- because "Insights" come from people.  I believe the company (aka. the employees), recognize that as we move from an industrial age, where winners and losers were defined by automation and efficiency…this new age will be require new thinking.  Efficiency focuses on the organizations, but Insight focuses on the Individual...and teams of individuals...working together to do something special.  In other words, we believe it will be our ability to foster, amplify, and aggregate human insight that will set Eastman apart -- and that's exciting.
cons: We are sometimes so focused on execution (a very "responsible" culture), that we can put our heads down and execute the wrong strategy.

pros: Great training programs but not everyone is allowed to have training to improve a skill set. Gives back to the community.
cons: Management team in NA with direct reports consists of males in authority making all decisions. It appears this is done on purpose and there are 10 managers in Logistics with reports and all are male. Somehow woman aren't qualified to supervise teams anymore. Management tends to focus on how to make themselves look good and will make decisions without knowing how it will impact their employees or the company. No respect to anyone  but expect more out of planners.  But there is no reward offered to them for going the extra mile. Management just adds more to each planner and is ok if planners work 12-14 hrs per day.

review_title: Do more with less and you dont get any more.
pros: For this area, it's one of the only option if you're wanting to work at a large company and have flexibility to switch roles/jobs without switching company.
cons: Employees are constantly asked to do more and more. Most employees felt like that's ok to be asked to be more efficient and work smarter, but there is no system in place to reward those that do outperform or perform well. Always asked to do better and soon as we don't, there are cuts and actions taken. If we do perform better and exceed expectation, no recognition other than "great job and here's next one that we need to do even better!"  This is not sustainable...

review_title: Great company for couples and families
pros: I have worked at Eastman for 23 years and the company has supported me and my husband in work/life balance decisions all through our careers.  Eastman has a very generous interpretation of the family leave policy, allowing both me and my husband to take family leave time consecutively after the births of our children.  Also, Eastman worked with me to adjust my work hours down to 25-30 hours for over 6 years while my children were young.  We have both been able to work in challenging jobs that allow for advancement without requiring a lot of travel, since both the manufacturing and corporate headquarters are in Kingsport.  Eastman also provides quite a lot of recreational opportunities for individuals and families (recreational club, hiking and outdoor club, photography, bridge, etc), and provides a lot of community support.  Job stability is also very good.  Compared to other chemical companies, Eastman has had very few layoffs in the last 10-15 years.
cons: It is a reasonably large company, and consequently, sometimes the red tape and muliple layers of management approvals and HR policies can be frustrating, but overall I could not have picked a better place to spend my career.

pros: Eastman offers a relatively stable employment situation in a safe community within a scenic southern US venue.  The location is idyllic in many ways with a number of recreational opportunities close by or within a short drive.  Work/life balance is available to those who are not driven toward stratospheric career achievement.  The site is very large and diverse, so opportunities for multiple assignments are plentiful if you so desire.  Base pay and bonuses are the best in the region; benchmarked to be "competitive" nationally.  Executive management at Eastman has improved substantially over the last 10 years.
cons: The pace of recent changes have left employees wondering what might be coming next.  Innovation is the buzz-word of the moment, but out-of-box thinking is not always appreciated.  Management has selective hearing, with few venues for grass-roots employees to be heard; arrogance abounds within leadership at Eastman. It's easy to get a sense of isolation because of the lack of communication many times.  Careers opportunities with potential for real advancement are not readily available to most employees.

review_title: A very class oriented place to work.  Would love to know how many positive reviews came from the blue collar workers.
job_title: Chemical Plant Operator in Kingsport, TN
pros: My co-workers are some of the finest people I have worked with, including my time in the military.  Many of them work hundreds of hours of overtime and strive to improve the processes and the work environment.
cons: If you wear coveralls your opinion doesnt matter much.  Much knowledge gained through years of experience is often ignored.  Auto mechanics may not design your vehicle but they know how to keep it running.  The same can be said for the operators.  Yes, we are punching a clock, but we try to be part of the solution and not part of the problem.

pros: I have worked for other companies and can say that the culture within Eastman Chemical is far more collaborative than I experienced at other chemical companies.  There is a sense of teamwork here, and the vast majority of people make decisions in the best interest of the overall company even if it hurts results in their area.  Also, the career opportunities are nearly endless with over 40 sites around the world.  Kingsport, in particular, is the location of a very large manufacturing site and is also the corporate headquarters, so it is not uncommon for employees to move back and forth between manufacturing and "business" roles.  Finally, pay and benefits are fair, and the company does care about maintaining reasonable work-life balance.
cons: Depending on where you work within Eastman, you can be in a smaller community that doesn't offer all the amenities of a larger city, like major league sports teams, shopping, and entertainment.  However, most sites are located within reasonable driving distance of such attractions.  Kingsport is a beautiful area with moderate climate, a short commute to work, friendly people, and good schools with lots of outdoor recreational opportunities, which helps offset some of the things a person might miss not being in a major city.

pros: Overall I really enjoy my job on a day to day basis.  By far, the best thing about Eastman is the people.  Most departments are team based and feel like a family.
cons:
I am concerned with how recent HR changes are affecting the company culture.  Last year, Eastman started a ranking system with a mandatory bottom 5%.  I've already seen the culture that once made Eastman great start to change as people become more competitive and focused on who will be thrown under the bottom 5% bus this year.  

Promotions are also few and far between.  By choosing to work at Eastman, I've set myself behind my peers at other companies with more appropriate promotion levels.  In addition, Eastman has forced flat budgets for the next 3 years.  More and more people are leaving because of the culture changes, but we dont have the budgets to replace them.  That leaves the rest of us to work long hours to pick up the slack.

review_title: Anniston obviously doesn't receive the benefits that Kingsport does
job_title: Operations in West End Anniston, AL
pros: It's a job and pays the bills. However the pros have become overshadowed by the cons.
cons: The benifits along with treatment and appreciation of employees took a drastic decline when purchased by Eastman. We don't have the on site fitness center or medical staff that Kingsport enjoys. Instead we lost our fitness reimbursement and insurance went to crap! Management treats employees as if they are stupid and refuse to take advice from seasoned employees when making decisions on the jobs that we run daily. Expressing concerns will cause retaliation from above. Supervision could care less about  the health, well being and general happiness of employees. We are expected to work horrible shift rotations and motivation to sacrifice our off time to help the company is nonexistent. Getting a answer from human resources is impossible and emails never get a response.  Our plant once offered the best benefits and pay in our area but now Walmart appears to be a better place to work!

review_title: Work culture, compensation, and morale improvements needed!
pros:
Hardworking, talented, and collaborative coworkers

Opportunity for a variety of roles as a chemical engineer

East Tennessee is a great area for families
cons:
The employee performance rating system (forced distribution) is significantly undermining the work culture. I have no problem with a common sense rating system and agree with rewarding better performers. The current performance rating system is flawed in many ways and needs to be replaced.

Employee compensation has remained relatively flat in the last 5-10 years (always "benchmarked" to remain average or slightly below average). This is inconsistent with management goals to outperform other companies and relentlessly pursue record earnings.

Too often, employee performance and promotions are judged based on who can talk well (sell themselves well). Supervisors need to be seek out peer feedback so they can accurately judge work performance.

Senior management constantly talks about the value of Eastman's people, but labor reductions imply otherwise.

pros:
Company is headed in the right direction if evaluating from only a shareholders perspective.
Terrible years from a talent retention perspective create many opportunities for those who choose to stay.
cons:
Culture fosters medocrity. The differential in pay for someone recieving the highest possible ranking (of which only a select few recieve) and "meeting expectations" is only a couple percentage points. This system demotivates the people at the top (Why should I continue working this hard for such a small pay increase?) and those at the bottom (Why should I work as hard as Jim since he's practically killing himself for next to nothing?). 

Promotion consideration largely determined by length of service rather than by aptitude or ability.

review_title: Commitment to location (Kingsport, TN) is a major consideration for career opportunities
job_title: Corporate Strategy Manager in Kingsport, TN
pros: Company is going through major business model change to catch up with the rest of the industry. 30% of employees approaching retirement age in the next few years. Therefore, lots of opportunities within the company. However, local connection or commitment to the location (Kingsport, TN) has become a major consideration for any career opportunities. Performance is secondary or even third tier consideration for career progress.
cons: Company HQ located in a very remote area, Kingsport, TN. Most of the people in the company still have a small town mind-set. Company policy rewards loyalty instead of performance. For example, if 2 people doing exactly the same job, one could have an office and makes much more than the other just because the prior has been with the company for longer time. This is such a disappointment for a global company. Another thing has bothered me personally is Eastman likes to get in employee's personal life. For example, almost anyone who joined the company and moved from outside of Kingsport, TN will be asked when they are going to buy a house in town. This question will be asked many times for years until they actually bought a house. I have seen people at all levels, even Director level, to be excluded from promotion because of not having a house in town.  Many people have left the company because of lack of career development opportunities.

review_title: If you like having your hand held as if you were a Kindergardener, then Eastman is the place to work.
pros: The only Pros I think I can really contribute towards Eastman is the wages.  They are somewhat higher than average for most of Eastern Tennessee.
cons: I often come to work and feel like I should have brought my lunch in a Scooby Doo lunch box and a Snoopy sleeping pad.  Our management acts though we are not competent enough to make personal decisions.  Example:  Make sure your sleeves are down, don't forget your goggles, you need gloves to handle a water hose.  Safety is a good thing and no one wants to go home injury free any more than I do, but there's a difference in being safety minded and completely going overboard.  Also, with the new clothing regulations for entering the company property, I often wonder if I'm entering Eastman or Chernobyl.
